answers.answer: I don't have Graves Disease, but we've had quite a few members with it, who got pregnant and had healthy babies, and who didn't die in the process.Adequate thyroid hormones are essential for the growth and development of a fetus, so you would have to keep close watch on your actual hormone (Free T3 and Free T4) levels, throughout the entire pregnancy.  It's recommended to have levels tested monthly during pregnancy.What are your actual current levels?  Please post them, with reference ranges, so we can better assess your situation.Do you still have symptoms of being hyper?

Thanks for responding so quickly barb. I was feeling fine on my PTU until about a month ago, when my heart started acting up again, I went to my cardiologist (easier to get in to see them than my endo) and they ordered a thyroid test. I didn't realize how ontop of my own labs I should be, so I just quickly jotted down what the nurse on the phone told me, I'm not sure what any of it means, but the lab results got me in to see my endo a few months earlier than my normal appointment (which was in december of this year). I see my endo on the 9th of sept. And I will ask for a print out of my labs. Right now all I have is this messy note I made of what the nurse told me:TSH normal 5.0 (0.34-5.60)3T3 normal 2.9 (2.3-4.2)T4 0.56 (0.61-1.12)She said it wasn't terrible, but with my symptoms bothering me I couldn't wait until december to be seen. I was first on 50mg PTU twice a day, and then uped to 50mg PTU three times a day. When I had to take 3 pills, I ended up forgetting the 3rd pill almost every time. Also, it was making my hair fall out like crazy so I was not pushing myself to remember. I've learned my lesson, and since my cardiologist appointment about a month agao I've only missed two doses. But my heart is still acting up. I am hoping to get ANOTHER test ordered by my endo for next month to see if my current perscription (when taken correctly) is enough, before letting her up the dose again.As far as the pregnancy thing goes, I've talked extensively with my endo about safety for the fetus, and chose PTU as a treatment instead of going with RAI or surgery since going hypo CAN be potentially worse on a fetus. I feel confident in my choice, tho I plan to do RAI in the future. However, I haven't really asked about MY safety during pregnancy. We are considering never getting pregnant because of the risks to my life, and I think it would help me if I heard some women with the same experience getting through their pregnancies, or not. My mother had preeclampsia with both pregnancies, and EVERY person in my family and extended family has some heart related medical problem. Heart disease kills almost everyone in my family, so I'm scared of the "heart failure" risk too. I'm sorry for my long, rambley posts, I'm very scatter brained naturally, and very disheartened about this pregnancy issue.

I'll start off by saying that I have hashi's instead of graves. I've had hypo symptoms for several years before pregnancy and always had a normal TSH until AFTER I gave birth. Since I never got morning sickness, and didnt show until way way later, I had very little to complain about, so during my pregnancy I would continually joke about how I could die giving birth so that my husband would feel guilty. I never even heard of preeclampsia until they told me that I would be having a cesarean and would not be allowed to leave the hospital until then. I felt perfectly fine and thought everyone was crazy. I was aware though that I had gained 12lbs in one week, but when I asked about it, that's when they sent me to the hospital for more testing. By this time I was going in every week, and apparently started having hypertension the week before, but they didnt tell me. The next time they checked, the nurse had left in a panic to get the doctor. When the doctor came in, she started mentioning something about HELLP syndrome, and a bunch of other medical jargon that I hadn't heard of. The excess weight was mostly water retention, but I assumed this was normal since pregnant women are supposed to have swollen feet, right?Anyway, pretty much you can't die from preeclampsia in the modern first world unless you decide for some reason to go all pioneer, birthing the child at home without any medical assistance. Your pressure is always monitored every time you go in for a check up, and the closer to time, you start going every other week, and eventually every week. Every visit they make you pee into a cup, which was how they confirmed my preeclampsia that eventful day. They basically suspected this the week before from the tests, they just kept it to themselves. You don't want to worry a pregnant lady, especially one with high blood pressure.I say that if you're able to conceive, go for it. Since you already have the diagnosis, they are going to continually monitor your thyroid levels, something they never did for me, and as long as they stay stable, you might not even get it. But you can always purchase your own blood pressure tester yourself and monitor it on your own daily, if worried. Also, you may want to check your weight each day once pregnant. Preeclampsia mostly only occurs during the last trimester, but if you noticed that you gained an insane amount of weight like I did, (5-15 in one week) then you'll have another red flag. The third red flag is if you notice bubbles in your urine. One of the deals with preeclampsia is that you have excess protein in your urine, which ends up causing bubbles. A forth red flag is chest pains. So if any of the four occur, you can tell your doctor and they'll bring you in for an earlier appointment to check.I ended up having a beautiful healthy baby at 37 and a half weeks (so just barely not a premmie) but she was pretty much done and had a full head of hair. If you are unable to conceive though, are worried that your future child might be born with physical or mental challenges, or just don't want to wreck your body even further, then by all means adopt. But if you, personally, truly want your own, then I don't see any reason why you should worry about preeclampsia. If it happens, it happens, but with all the monitoring going on, it shouldn't really become an issue, especially since going in, they know that 1) you have a an autoimmune disease, 2) have a thyroid condition, and 3) have a family history of preeclampsia.They released me from the hospital though still with high blood pressure, but I guess they thought it was safe enough to let me go. (Your own bedroom is going to be more peaceful than a hospital room) I ended up being the only one in the elevator who saw the really cool fireworks, but I just wanted to go home, so I kept this to myself. Later that night (4am) I woke up to a horrible migraine. I had never experienced such a thing before. It was internal, inner right, not on the outside like normal headaches. It grew in intensity until I woke up, and then lessened. I think it might've been a blood clot that I was passing. Im not sure if the hypertension caused that. So, if you're worried, tell the doctor/nurse everything. Don't just keep it to yourself, like I tended to do.However, if it were me, and I was currently having heart issues, I'd wait. Also, since your medication is making your hair fall out, I'd also wait until your body adjusts to it.

I had pre-enclampsia/toxemia with my pregnancy. I had my son induced 4 weeks early. Yes he was a preemie, but I did not know neither did my doctor I had graves until after the birth.I went in for my usual pregnancy check up and was never allowed to leave, taken to the ER (I did not notice any symptoms and honestly the ones I did have I assumed were related to being pregnant) and delivered him that same night.Now about 6 months after his birth I started having symptoms really bad due to graves/hyper, long story short I ended up having RAI & then TT. I did go through two thyroid storms after his birth.My son is now going on 20 and is a very fit healthy adult. Not little or short by any means...He could probably stand to gain maybe a few pounds, but he works out and runs.

Maybe I'm over-reacting about my own actual risk. You got pretty far along in your pregnancy with untreated graves, and both you and your son are happy campers now! Wow. I thought what happened to you would end up happening to me (even if my levels were great when I concieved, I feared everything would go hay-wire because that's my luck). But I guess that's really only what happens to UNTREATED graves? Hmmm. Thank you all so much. I greeted my husband after work yesterday in tears, I was feeling sorry for myself, after my sister announced her 2nd twin pregnancy that morning. And I had convinced myself I'd never survive a pregnancy, and I'd never know that joy. I can't wait to greet him tonight with news of people who have been through this. With not a tear shed. :) thank you. This gives me hope

I thought my symptoms would be different.The first symptom i noticed coming back was my "hulk" episodes as I call them, where I get irritated to the point where I get inraged.Then I noticed I was sleeping WAY more often, sometimes all day.Then I realized my muscles were weakening again, I had been walking 6 miles, easy peasy, and now my basement steps are becoming difficult.Then my heart went crazy.My hair started falling out as soon as I was taken from two 50mg PTU to three 50mg PTU.Maybe 150mg a day is too much. I guess it is if I'm hypo. MAYBE MY HAIR WILL STOP FALLING OUT!!!!!! That would be awesome! :) thank you for the insight. Do my symptoms match hypo symtoms too? I've developed anxiety now that I'm on ptu. Maybe I'm just weird.

Some symptoms can cross over and apply to either/both hyper and hypo.What antibody tests were done to confirm Graves Disease?  TSI is the definitive test for Graves and if you didn't have that, you might have Hashimoto's, instead - or maybe in addition to.  With Hashimoto's, it's not uncommon to "swing" from hyper to hypo and even into normal periods.

I don't know what the tests were, I was swept up in a scarey whirl wind of new doctors, I didn't even know what to ask them. Here's what I remember of the whole "getting diagnosed" events:I had probably 20 E.K.G.s in the span of two years (or is that the brain waves.. Maybe E.E.G. is the heart one?) And I had to wear a heart montior, and nothing caught my tachycardia until the last one. Then I mentioned off hand to my doctor (who had been trying so hard to figure out what my problem was for a year) that my nails kept breaking off below the nailbed. He immediately frowned and went for my throat. He poked and squeezed and said it felt a little enlarged and ordered ANOTHER ekg (eeg?) For my heart and an ultrasound of my "goiter" and lab work. The heart thingy found my tachycardia and I guess they had a tip off from either the ultrasound or the labs, I don't know, I didn't ask. I just sat there in shock when he said I needed to see a cardiologist and an endochronologist (I had no idea what an endo was).I went to the endo, she had me go to the hospital for a test. They gave me a readioactive-iodine pill (I was super freaked out by that) and then I layed on a bed in a dark room not allowed to move an inch, while this giant machine sat over my throat and I guess photographed how my thyroid and the iodine reacted together or something? I'm not sure. It took a long time.I might have had another lab done, I'm not sure. When I went back to see the endo she said it was graves disease. (Which sounded like a death sentence because of the word "grave") then I went back to her and we discussed treatment options. (At some point I saw my cardiologist too during all that).

The test done in the hospital would have been an RAIU - Radioactive iodine uptake.  (RAIU) is a test of thyroid function. It measures how much radioactive iodine is taken up by the thyroid gland in a certain time period.  While it can be a valuable test, it shouldn't take the place of the antibody tests.The only test that can definitively diagnose Graves is the Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin (TSI) blood test.  If you didn't have that, you might not even have Graves Disease.Other tests you should get, if you haven't had them already, are Thyroid Peroxidase Antibodies (TPOab) and Thyroglobulin Antibodies (TgAB).  These are the tests that would diagnose Hashimoto's Thyroiditis.  You need them both, because some people have one, some have the other, some have both.Some people automatically equate hyper with Graves, but that's not always the case.  As I noted above, some symptoms can "cross over" and apply to either hyper or hypo and with Hashimoto's, it's not the least uncommon to swing from hyper to hypo to normal, in the early stages.  Rarely, a person can be diagnosed with both Graves and Hashimoto's.You should get copies of all your blood work and other test results to make sure you are getting the proper tests and treatment.  If you are in the U.S. your doctor is required, by law, to provide you with copies of your labs/test results, upon request.

question: Hi, this is my first time finding this site. I have been struggling with Grave's disease symptoms since about 2005. I was finally correctly diagnosed in 2011. I chose to take PTU and a beta blocker, since my endo said it was safe for the baby.But now my husband and I are worried about the risk of pre-enclampsia, heart failure, and thyroid storm brought on from pregnancy complications. My husband says even though its a small risk, he would rather adopt than put me at risk of death, leaving him and an infant without me. I'm worried about that too. I've talked with the doctors and they continue to say that once my levels are controled there's no reason for graves patients to worry. And then they also say my risk of the above is higher. I think my question is, really just an effort to hear some real-life experience of women who have had pregnancies with graves disease, and also, does anyone know anybody who died from prgnancy/labor/postpartum-thyroid storm, heart failure or pre-eclampsia? I know the facts, but I don't know ANYONE with the disease who has any personal stories to share. I am very upset at both options, risking death when I could have avoided it, or never ever experiencing pregnancy and giving birth to our child. I'm fine with adopting (and we definitely will), but I always thought I'd be pregnant oneday too. Any personal experience is helpful and I desperately await it.
